headline: CrowdStrike founder Kurtz buys into Mercedes F1 team
summary:
STORY: CrowdStrike founder and chief executive George Kurtz has bought into the Mercedes Formula One team.

Kurtz is taking 15% of the one-third stake held by principal Toto Wolff, both parties announced on Thursday.

No financial details were given for the personal acquisition but media reports last week said the deal valued the former champions at a record $6 billion.

Wolff, Mercedes-Benz and Jim Ratcliffe's petrochemicals giant Ineos each hold one-third stakes and the governance and leadership of the team will not be affected by the deal.

Kurtz will become the team's technology adviser and joins the strategic steering committee alongside Wolff, Ratcliffe and Mercedes-Benz chairman Ola Kaellenius.

In an interview with reporters, Kurtz said he sees a great opportunity to grow the sport, particularly in the U.S. market.

He said he had total alignment with Wolff, subscribed to his leadership style and had been discussing taking a stake for several years.

He ruled out one day taking on a greater role in the team, saying his focus remains with Cybersecurity company CrowdStrike.

CrowdStrike has been a team partner since 2019 with branding on the car and apparel.

Mercedes won eight constructors' titles in a row from 2014 to 2021, and are currently second overall behind champions McLaren, who also use the German manufacturer's engines.
